commentBody:
I learned something yesterday about streaks.  Sorry about my strange comment about there being so few comments.  I usually do the puzzle after dinner while my husband does the dishes.  (I cook, he cleans.)  Last night we had late dinner and when I sat down to do the puzzle I did the newest one, not noticing that it was already the Wed puzzle.  After 7 pm PST.  I finished it, went to read column and comments as always, and was so surprised at only 75 comments.

Before going to bed -- now 11 pm PST -- I realized I hadn't finished the other puzzles, so went to do them.  That's when I noticed I'd done Wed, but never Tuesday!  I assumed my streak was blown.  But I did Tuesday before midnight, so it was still Tues, and the Stats page kept my streak!

I knew that if I missed a day and did it before I did the next day's that the streak would remain.  But I didn't know I could do them out of order if the earlier one finished on its correct day.

I've done 2800  puzzles, but streak is only 45 days, so not a big deal to lose it.  Longest is 625 days, but usually every couple of months I miss a day or two and start the streak over.  Not a big deal to me.  

But now it's Wed and the puzzle is already finished -- so I'm writing this long harrangue on the Thursday comments.  Again, it's after 10 pm in New York....
I know that LEGOS is used in common usage, but I can't find any major dictionary that allows it as acceptable plural form (as opposed to the preferred Lego bricks)

Much love to you in your new chapter of life, Deb!

Puzzle comments to come, just wanted to get that in.

Deb, Thanks for helping keep me sane (saner?) for the past several years.  Like a great teacher, you will never know how many lives you‚Äôve touched through your kindness, humor, patience and infectious enthusiasm for crosswords.  I can tell you: 48,973.  Give or take.

Finished this pleasant puzzle a few minutes ago sans KUDO from the software, and since then have been unable to find my error(s).  

In any cae, this was a cute theme, one that's been used before (but that's not a problem), that made it fun to work out the individual theme answers. I always appreciate a puzzle where I am motivated to work out the theme answers in order to solve the puzzle.

On the other hand, the non-theme answers were, in my opinion, unnecessarily easy, with a very large proportion that would be gimmes or near-gimmes for experienced solvers.

On the third hand, I liked seeing the word GROTTOES, since GROTTO enjoys finding itself among the dozens and dozens of my favorite words.

The one that vexed me for a moment was 19 Down ‚Äî ‚Äúthings caddies carry‚Äù

I was stuck on TEES, and it was only on the ‚ÄúKeep Trying‚Äù warning that I saw it was actually TEAS. And no, I‚Äôm not a golf nut.

Not only was that aspect of the construction clever, but it was fun to see that each WHEEL began with on O, and that each themer had something circular in it (ROLL, ROUND, HOOPS, LOOPS). Regarding pluralizing LEGO: The "adjective not noun" thing is a matter of branding, not law.  There is also precedent in English for noun-ifying adjectives -- for example, the use of "red" for "red wine" -- and for pluralizing thereof ("we have a selection of reds today". So I am totally fine with "Legos".  

More generally: had bar before PUB (right concept, wrong name), HOwl before HOOT, tptb (the powers that be) before LDRS, and -- somewhat embarrassingly -- pig, plus a sense of alarm, for "non-human source of spam". 

I also had a moment where I hadn't yet figured out the trick but had enough crossings to put SHOOTShOOPS, which meant "speech fillers" was UHh ... plausible except for the plural agreement. I'd had s in that square for a while (the answer could have been uh or um or er, but it seemed likely to be __S), but changed it when SHOOTSSOOPS seemed implausible. Silly me. 

Anyway. Fun puzzle. Deb, we will miss you but I have faith you will get up to something awesome in your new spare time...

Deb, I hope we meet on a future travel. I have really enjoyed your columns and humor. Now you can travel the rivers you've only read about in puzzles. What's the capital of Samoa? Now you can find out.

Was it intentional that we have a clue about a two-cent piece, with a picture of a ROLL of pennies in the column, on the day after the US Mint produced its final batch of pennies? https://www.nytimes.com/2025/11/12/business/penny-coin-legacy.html

Here's my 2 cents for today... Today US minted its last one-cent coin. 150+ years ago (1864-1873), the US also minted copper two-cent coins. They had the same composition as one-cent coins and exactly double the weight. They never really caught on and were discontinued. Yet the Eurozone makes 1- and 2-cent coins, and the UK has 1- and 2-penny coins, and those circulate freely. Odd that the 2-cent denomination didn't last in the US. 

Likewise, Eurozone and UK 50c/50p coins also circulate freely, whereas you rarely see half dollars in the US. Canada mints 50c coins, but they're rarely seen; I guess they take after the US in that respect?

On the other hand, figuring out how the theme entry words looped around would have been more of a challenge‚Äîa welcome one for some masochi‚Ä¶ er‚Ä¶ solvers like me. My request to the IT team would be to be able to opt out of shaded squares if overlays are turned off in settings. 

This is in no way a criticism of the puzzle, by the way. I really enjoyed it. Thanks, Kyle.

Deb,

For this past decade and a half, you have made readers and solvers such as myself feel less alone through a grand camaraderie. You have crafted a warm, edifying space where we all could relish our shared love of wordplay together, commiserate with each other over difficult puzzles, and marvel at the creativity of the constructions we are so honored to behold.

Puzzles are a beautiful enterprise, and it was wonderful to have you at the helm here, modeling kindness and joy. This is bittersweet, of course, but I can sense the robust opportunity and joie de vivre in a line such as this:

"I am endlessly curious about this world we live in and would like to see more of it. I will have the time to read all the books I never got to, and my family are looking forward to seeing more of me."

And it is my most fervent wish that your retirement is filled with every good thing that you seek (including lots and lots of puns).

Thank you, Deb. It has been an honor having you here.

Really NYT? No fact checking? 
Why Is Nobel Memorial Prize In Economic Sciences Not A Real Nobel ...
The official name of the economics Nobel Prize is the Sveriges Riksbank Prize in Economic Sciences in Memory of Alfred Nobel. While commonly called the Nobel Prize in Economics, it is technically a memorial prize established by Sweden's central bank

I‚Äôve branched out into cryptics (love wordplay), other crosswords (NYT will always be my first love), and logic puzzles. I‚Äôm so grateful to the entire NYT Games team, all the constructors, and the games community for creating this wonderful puzzle which sustains and enriches so many of us. Thank you, Deb, and best of luck on your next adventures!

I enjoyed the puzzle.

I‚Äôm always kind to debut instructors and will be again today, especially to a fellow Badger (I grew up in Wisconsin and went to med school in Madison). But I will give some constructive criticism. This wasn‚Äôt a bad puzzle at all and shows promise, but if you didn‚Äôt know this was a new constructor you might guess it. A lot of really questionable fill that a more seasoned constructor might have worked around‚ÄîKUDO, LDRS, OHCMON, DCUP‚Äîand three letter glue like PEE and UHS and AHH. Some questionable clues that may or may not be the constructor‚Äôs fault‚Äî‚Äúmake it‚Äù? Like ‚Äúmake a TAG‚Äù in baseball? MARS as something in the Milky Way? Um, so is my dog‚Äôs left ear and on a relative scale of things that happen to be in the galaxy, not much different. 
On the plus side, a clever theme idea, but a bit of a letdown after a stellar early week‚Äîwould have been better switched with yesterday‚Äôs where it would have been a fine Wednesday theme. Also suited more for a Wednesday as a challenge, the top was quite easy, the bottom a bit harder.
I did have to flyspeck at the end (I see I wasn‚Äôt the only one)‚ÄîI had TEAS right (nice misdirect!) and BADRAP right  (could‚Äôve been BADREP) but had SHOOTSH(OMEH)OOPS which AI, when I asked it, encouraged me was a thing (it‚Äôs not)‚Äînot your fault it had to be UHS not UHH, but I had to read the column to be set straight.
So, congrats on your debut‚Äîthis was quite an amusing theme despite all my nitpicking, and I look forward to more from you in the future!

Congratulations Deb on the retirement!  It's great that you are leaving on your own terms.  I will be sorry to see your byline go.  Your warm thoughts are reflected back from the motley crew here.  We always appreciate what has to be a tricky job, even if we rarely say it.

About the column: I remember coming here for the first few times, some years ago (and I still think of myself as a noob) I immediately was affected by the welcoming warmth, wit and intelligence of Deb's columns, their patience, the lack of condescension, the geniality. This set the tone for the commenters, too, and peace reigned throughout the land. I also think Caitlin and Sam will be fine stewards forward of your singular achievement here, in creating such a wide and inclusive tent, that allows us noobs to mingle with such esteemed peers. It's a special place and a lot of it was your doing, Deb.

Puzzle: I loved the loop-dee-loops, extra points (!) for MISSES crossing SHOOTS SOME HOOPS -- that would be me! It may be that I'm spoiled but hey if your revealer is going to be WHEELS, then there better be some cool graphic of spinnin' wheels once we get a gold star, and I felt positively gypped. 

Just for yuks I started in the bottom left and dutifully filled in ROF APPLAUSE. I stared at it for a few seconds, then decided it must be Roll On the Floor Applause, like the audience is so chuffed by what they just saw that they're rolling around in the aisles, clapping and kicking up their legs. We've all been to performances like that at some point in our lives. 

Can't a pessimist be a hoper, too? That would be me.

A common mistake but there is no Nobel Prize awarded for ECONomics. The 5 Nobel Prize categories are peace, literature, physics, chemistry, medicine. The economics prize was a later addition named ‚Äúin memory of‚Äù Nobel, but is not one of the 5 Nobel Prizes.

I‚Äôm happy for you and your opportunity to fill your hours with only things you want to do, but sad for myself and others as we are going to miss you something fierce. Thanks for giving us a heads up and time to get acclimated with the idea.

Just want to add my own note of gratitude to Deb for so many fine columns. When I subscribed five years ago and ventured into Wordplay, her column was the first thing I saw. Oh Deb, you have never failed to support us, without ever making us feel that we are dummies: You gracefully encouraged the newbies, bolstered the middle ground, and expressed camaraderie for the wizards. It can't have been easy to strike a perfect tone for all of us, but you did it, and I, for one, am afraid I took it for granted that you would always be here.

Despite my sudden attack of separation anxiety and feeling SILOED, I am wishing you a beautiful, deadline-free retirement, full of adventure and opportunities for exploration. There is so much to look forward to now!

About this puzzle, Kyle Perkins, it is almost impossible to believe that it is your debut. The fill was very hard for me in places, which resulted in a Saturday-timed solve.

I had to look up IHOP (by now I have learned this brand, but of course constructors or editors keep finding ways to clue it ever more arcanely) and ROOK (slang is my Achilles's heel; the dictionary tells me this usage is old-fashioned informal, so pretty much beyond me), and ESP (I just couldn't be bothered).

I'm confused by TAG meaning "make it". I'm finding it difficult to see how it would work. Is it about a game of tag? But shouldn't then the clue be: make "it"? If so, meh. I really dislike it when language is misused for misdirection.

I wish AAH/AhH were banned from these crosswords. It's such blatant filler, and afflicted by the Kea/Loa virus, too.

Can't say I liked the crosswordese HOPER. It just looks so wrong ü´§

Why is her mouth in the wrong place for a pig, and why, god, *why* are both her flipping eyes on one side of her *nose* üò≥. I'm soooo glad she never appeared in any of my nightmares... But at least knowing of her gave me OINK today.

So yeah, I enjoyed the theme but my personal solving experience was marred by some of the fill.

I don't normally go in for gimmicks, I absolutely loved this one! Not using the rebus function made this a much more solidly crafted puzzle experience for me. I'd love to see similar overlap formatting in other crosswords, especially in place of rebuses, because rebuses, when they aren't gimmicky, still require a higher level of inference than I feel is appropriate for all but the most difficult Sunday puzzles.

(But I think I speak for many of us when I say no thanks for the ear worm! These things should come with something akin to a spoiler alert! ‚ÄúBeware, ear worm approaching In the next paragraph!‚Äù)

Once I started reading your articles, I finally understood how to approach solving every day of the week. Now I am up to a 2+ year streak. Thank you!!

Frankly, I would‚Äôve rage quit these puzzles long ago if it weren‚Äôt for your tips, tricks, and guidance. And of course that HOPER attitude!

This is a hard theme to pull off, as the gray squares, which have to be filled in with specific letters, greatly restrict the words that can go into the grid‚Äôs white squares.  Also, the horizontal theme answers have to be of certain lengths to meet symmetry, and coming up with this set had to be a bear.

Despite these roadblocks, this grid is sprinkled with beauty: MUESLI, ROUND OF APPLAUSE, PESTER, SPONGES (as clued), PULL FOR, GROTTOEES, THROW FOR A LOOP, and OH C‚ÄôMON.  Those last two, by the way, are NYT answer debuts.

Technically, the prize in Economics is called "Sveriges Riksbank Prize in Economic Sciences in memory of Alfred Nobel."  The Nobel Prizes are funded by the Nobel estate and the Econ prize is funded by Sweden's central bank.

I would just like to point out that, contrary to a common misunderstanding, the canned meat that contains bot flesh is not actual Spam. Bot was only used in a special series of canned meats pressed by the Swiss Legos Institute ‚Äúin honour of Spam‚Äù. That canned product was officially sold as Smoove Kudo.

Other than that, no bones to pick. Good puzzle.

Deb - my goodness, you'll be missed!  As a retirement gift, allow me to share the earworm cure my husband and I stumbled across.  (His lifelong love of music kicked off with a few years following the Grateful Dead as a young man, and I've been a working classical musician for nearly 40 years, so we have a wide variety of earworms available to us.)

We fight earworms with ALL the earworms.  Wheels on the Bus?  Start singing bits of every earworm you can think of.  Your brain will be like a toddler who has just been given more candy than they can hold in two hands.  Then turn on music you actually want to listen to, and let your brain move on from the earworms.

I can personally recommend the Kars for Kids jingle, the 1962 hit Bobby's Girl, Baby Shark (doo doo doo doo), Feliz Navidad, Uptown Funk, the chorus of I'm Gonna Be (500 Miles), and various bits of incidental music from the opera Carmen.
The best and original version of the song is Round and Round by Perry Como 1957.

I may be just a softie about this but  I like to think that the 1- and 2-dollar coins succeeded in Canada because they are beautiful objects.
The loonie (so called because it has a portrait of a floating  loon) is a polygon (i.e., not just a smooth circle) with a dark gold patina. It ages well and is a completely everyday object here. Occasionally, a special edition is minted. For the Vancouver Olympics, the loon was shown wings lifted amid splashing water, with the Olympic rings above.
The $2 coin, inevitably called the toonie, shows a polar bear against a rocky background. Its format consists of a silver rim surrounding a gold-coloured central insert. It had a rough start; in the earliest coins, the inserts sometimes popped out of the frames! It too has had some special editions, including one in which the polar bear is shown with two cubs.
Both are solid, easy to handle, visually and tactilely distinctive,  and lovely to look at.
